abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Growth Poles
            Project for Madagascar were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: in the absence of stability,
            leadership and ownership at the central government level,
            project implementation can still be effective if engagement
            at local government levels is high and there is strong
            project management. Sufficient institutional support and
            governance capacity building should be integrated into
            growth poles projects to promote their durability and
            replicability. Collaborative and multi-sector Bank projects
            can be useful in development contexts where there are
            multi-dimensional constraints, provided there is a uniform
            standard of quality in project design and implementation
            among the different participating units. Concentrating
            investments in spatially-limited areas with lean governance
            structures can help mitigate the risks associated with a
            complex design, weak implementation capacity, and the thin
            spreading of resources.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Integrated Growth Poles
            Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The resettlement action plan (RAP) for
            the Madagascar Integrated Growth Poles Project includes the
            country ' s regulatory and legal frameworks, and the
            Bank ' s safeguard policies, and principles for
            resettlement, stipulating the criteria for ensuring
            compensation to project affected people (PAP) as required,
            due to subprojects implementation. The RAP addresses the
            following mitigating measures: cultural heritage sites are
            to be protected and respected in compliance with the country
            ' s legislation, and the Bank safeguards policy;
            mitigation measures for project affected people (PAP) will
            ensure that PAPs will gain benefit from the project and
            improve their standard of living; measures necessary to
            mitigate adverse impacts will be determined with
            participation of the displaced persons during design and
            implementation of the project; addressing the needs of
            displaced PAPs will be a priority during periods of
            transition and adaptation to new or temporary settlements;
            compensation to PAPs for the cost of losses from involuntary
            relocation, as required; and the previous level of community
            services and access to resources will be maintained or
            improved after resettlement.

display_title.display_title:
Madagascar - Integrated Growth
            Poles Project : resettlement plan : Plan de reinstallation involontaire

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Integrated Growth Poles
            Project : social  and environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social impact
            assessment of the Madagascar Integrated Growth Poles Project
            presents the environmental assessments for each of three
            strategic regions of the country: the district of Nosy Be,
            the Antananarivo / Antsirabe axis, and the district of
            Tolagnaro. The report comprises a social assessment and
            cultural policy framework, identifies environmental impacts,
            and proposes mitigation measures aimed at integrating
            environmental and social dimensions into regional
            development, specifically, into the medium- and long-term
            development endeavors of each of the poles. It ensures that
            tourism development is sustainable in environmental and
            social terms. It also seeks to rationalize future
            subprojects. Anticipated impacts include soil erosion and
            sedimentation, loss of biodiversity, coral destruction due
            to starfish proliferation, water contamination from human
            pollutants, economic loss, disappearance of animal species,
            and, restricted access to land for the population and
            traffic congestion, further diminution of cultivable land,
            destruction of ancient buildings and homes, degradation of
            the marine environment and beaches from tourism activities,
            air pollution, disrespect of cultural taboos and moral
            values, and loss of cultural identity and increased sexual
            tourism. Some recommended mitigations include: signage and
            traffic management, installing drainage systems, building
            repair, land use management, public education and publicity
            campaigns about the risks of sexually transmitted diseases,
            promotion of public health, protection of water resources,
            installing latrines, privatizing garbage collection,
            feasibility studies on incineration, composting and biogas
            production, installing mechanisms to control air pollution
            including dust dispersion, scheduling work during normal
            business hours, repairing and maintaining transport
            vehicles, using other means to minimize noise such as
            planting a greenbelt along transport corridors, restoring
            land and woods, carefully handling hazardous substances,
            avoiding traveling through water courses, conserving
            vegetation, planning for emergencies, locating work camps at
            a reasonable distance from villages, and involving local
            authorities in operational activities and ensuring
            women's representation.
